{{about|the artist|the journalist|Ellie Harrison (journalist)}} {{Multiple issues| {{BLP primary sources|date=March 2017}} {{COI|date=November 2016}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Use British English|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox artist | name = Ellie Harrison | image = File:Ellie_Harrison,_Daily_Data_Logger,_2005.jpg | image_size = | alt = Ellie Harrison, Daily Data Logger (2005) | caption = Ellie Harrison, ''Daily Data Logger'' (2005) | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1979}} | birth_place = London, England | nationality = British | training = [[Nottingham Trent University]]
[[Goldsmiths College]]
[[Glasgow School of Art]] | website = [http://www.ellieharrison.com/ www.ellieharrison.com] }} '''Ellie Harrison''' (born 1979) is a British artist known for her use of large quantities of data, collected through labour-intensive games, trials, systems and experiments, and, more recently, for her activist work campaigning for the [[Renationalisation of British Rail|re-nationalisation of Britain's railways]].{{cite news | last = Martin | first = Andrew | date = 2015-08-08 | title = Let a Public Train take the Strain | url = https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/aug/07/andy-burnham-railway-unity-renationalising | newspaper = The Guardian | page = 33 | location = London & Manchester | publisher = Guardian News & Media | accessdate = 2015-08-24 }} She is based in [[Glasgow]], Scotland and in April 2013 was appointed Lecturer (Teaching & Research) in Contemporary Art Practices at [[Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art and Design]]. == Early life and education == Brought up in [[Ealing]] in west London, Harrison attended [[Drayton Manor High School]] until the age of 18.{{cite news | last = Morgan | first = Steve | date = 2002-03-08 | title = Hard Act to Swallow | url = http://www.eat22.com/press/020308gazette.pdf | newspaper = Ealing & Acton Gazette | page = 19 | location = London | publisher = Trinity Mirror plc | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} After completing a Foundation Diploma in Art & Design at [[West Thames College]] in Hounslow, she went on to study Fine Art at [[Nottingham Trent University]] from 1998 – 2001 and at [[Goldsmiths College]] from 2002 – 2003. She moved to Scotland in 2008 to undertake a Leverhulme Scholarship on the Master of Fine Art course at [[Glasgow School of Art]],{{cite web | url = http://www.gsamfa.com/2010/ellie_harrison.php | title = Ellie Harrison | date = 2010-06-12 | website = Master of Fine Art Online Catalogue | publisher = Glasgow School of Art | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} where her degree show ''Press Release'', exhibited at the [[CCA Glasgow]] in 2010, consisted of news coverage about her work.{{cite news | last = Jeffrey | first = Moira | date = 2010-06-06 | title = The Finished Article | url = http://www.ellieharrison.com/pdf/pr-scotlandonsunday.pdf | newspaper = Scotland on Sunday Review | page = 7 | location = Edinburgh | publisher = The Scotsman Publications Limited | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} == Early work == Harrison first became known for her 2002 work ''Eat 22'', for which she photographed and recorded information about everything she ate for a year.{{cite web | url =http://www.bbc.co.uk/nottingham/spotlight/2002/03/photographic_diet.shtml | title = Graduate's Snappy Diet | date = 2002-03-12 | website = BBC Nottingham | publisher = BBC | accessdate = 2014-05-01 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20050816151110/http://www.bbc.co.uk/nottingham/spotlight/2002/03/photographic_diet.shtml | archivedate = 16 August 2005 }} She published the images online on a weekly basis throughout that year{{cite web | url = http://blog.wellcomecollection.org/2014/01/17/object-of-the-month-eat-22-an-interview-with-ellie-harrison/ | last = Morgan | first = Charlie | title = Object of the Month: Eat 22 (An Interview with Ellie Harrison) | date = 2014-01-17 | website = Wellcome Collection Blog | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} as an early example of [[photo blog]]ging.{{cite book | last = Colson | first = Richard | date = 2007-11-19 | title = The Fundamentals of Digital Art | url = http://www.bloomsbury.com/uk/the-fundamentals-of-digital-art-9782940439928/ | pages = 68–69 | location = London | publisher = AVA Publishing | isbn = 978-2-940373-58-1 | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} The project received international attention, featuring in the press in India, Taiwan, Czech Republic, France, Sweden, the US and across the UK.{{cite web | url = http://www.eat22.com/press.html | title = Press | date = 2007-06-21 | website = Eat 22 | publisher = Ellie Harrison | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }}{{better source|date=June 2014}} In 2003, the high-speed animated film of all 1,640 of the ''Eat 22'' photos was included in the exhibition ''Treat Yourself'' at the [[Science Museum, London]]{{cite book |last = Arnold |first = Ken |date = 2003-05-26 |title = Treat Yourself: Health Consumers in a Medical Age |url = http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/en/treatyourself/ |page = 82 |location = London |publisher = Science Museum |isbn = 18-41-29044-0 |accessdate = 2014-05-01 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131005163606/http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/en/treatyourself/ |archivedate = 5 October 2013 |df = dmy-all }} and in 2007 was put on permanent display at the [[Wellcome Collection]], London.{{cite book | last = Kohn | first = Marek | date = 2012-07-12 | title = A Guide for the Incurably Curious | url = http://www.wellcomecollection.org/visit-us/a-guide-for-the-curious.aspx | pages = 76–77 | location = London | publisher = Wellcome Collection | isbn = 978-0-9570285-1-7 | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} Harrison then went on to complete a series of large-scale "data collecting" projects{{cite book | last1 = O'Reilly | first1 = Sally | last2 = Jones | first2 = Hannah | last3 = Harrison | first3 = Ellie | date = 2009-04-23 | title = Confessions of a Recovering Data Collector | url = http://www.ellieharrison.com/confessions | location = Plymouth | publisher = Plymouth College of Art | isbn = 978-0-9557491-3-1 | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} including ''Gold Card Adventures'' (September 2002 – September 2003). She undertook this next project the year before the automated [[Oystercard]] system was introduced on London Transport, by manually recording the total distance of all the journeys she made on [[London Underground]] and on local buses for a period of one year, which amounted to more than 9,210 km.{{cite book |last = Dillon |first = Tamsin |date = 2007-11-27 |title = Platform for Art: Art on the Underground |url = http://blackdogonline.com/media/sales/PlatformArt.pdf |page = 91 |location = London |publisher = Black Dog Publishing |isbn = 978-1-906155-06-3 |accessdate = 2014-05-01 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160304125203/http://blackdogonline.com/media/sales/PlatformArt.pdf |archivedate = 4 March 2016 |df = dmy-all }} The resulting exhibition ''Gold Card Adventures'' (named after the yearly [[Travelcard]] that she used), took place at [[Piccadilly Circus tube station]] in 2005 as part of the [[Art on the Underground]] scheme.{{cite web | url = http://art.tfl.gov.uk/projects/ellie-harrison/ | last = Dillon | first = Tamsin | title = Gold Card Adventures | date = 2005-01-17 | website = Art on the Underground | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} In 2005 to 2006, Harrison curated ''Day-to-Day Data'', a group exhibition of "artists who collect list, database and absurdly analyse the data of everyday life".{{cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/nottingham/content/articles/2005/07/05/day_to_day_data_event_feature.shtml | title = Day-to-Day Data | date = 2005-07-05 | website = BBC Nottingham | publisher = BBC | accessdate = 2014-05-01 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090927012755/http://www.bbc.co.uk/nottingham/content/articles/2005/07/05/day_to_day_data_event_feature.shtml | archivedate = 27 September 2009 }} The exhibition toured the UK, visiting Danielle Arnaud contemporary art, London, [[Aspex Gallery]], Portsmouth and Angel Row Gallery, Nottingham. It was accompanied by a publication, a web-based exhibition and a symposium that took place at the [[Institute of Contemporary Arts]], London on 18 March 2006.{{cite web | url = http://www.daytodaydata.com/ | title = Day-to-Day Data | date = 2006-03-18 | website = Exhibition Website | publisher = Arts Council England | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} Harrison's early "data collecting" projects were examples of what is now referred to as [[life-logging]] or the [[quantified self]].{{cite book | last1 = Gee | first1 = Emily | last2 = Myerson | first2 = Jeremy | date = 2013-12-12 | title = Time & Motion: Redefining Working Life | url = http://liverpooluniversitypress.co.uk/products/61037 | pages = 120–123 | location = Liverpool | publisher = Liverpool University Press & FACT | isbn = 978-1-846319-66-2 | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} At the height of this work in 2005, she created the ''Daily Data Logger'' character{{cite journal | last = Briers | first = David | date = 2006-04-01 | title = Insignificance | url = http://www.ellieharrison.com/pdf/insignificance.pdf | pages = 7–10 | journal = Art Monthly | location = London | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} described as "an enthusiastic, data-collecting obsessive so keen on measuring / quantifying the things that surround her that she permanently dresses in a tracksuit (for easy manoeuvrability) and wears a utility belt jam-packed with data collecting devices".{{cite book | last1 = Highmore | first1 = Ben | last2 = Cohen | first2 = Kris | last3 = Harrison | first3 = Ellie | date = 2005-07-20 | title = Day-to-Day Data | url = http://www.daytodaydata.com/publication.html | pages = 32–35 | location = Nottingham | publisher = Angel Row Gallery | isbn = 978-0-905634-71-5 | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} Her final major "data collecting" project was the three-year ''Tea Blog'' (1 January 2006 – 31 December 2008), for which she published online what she was thinking about every time she had a hot drink. As a very early example of [[microblogging]], the popularity of Harrison's ''Tea Blog'', prefigured that of the [[Twitter]] platform, which did not launch until mid 2006.{{cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/nottingham/content/articles/2008/01/02/ellie_harrison_tea_blog_feature.shtml | title = Two Years of Tea Blog | date = 2008-01-03 | website = BBC Nottingham | publisher = BBC | accessdate = 2014-05-01 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090105185404/http://www.bbc.co.uk/nottingham/content/articles/2008/01/02/ellie_harrison_tea_blog_feature.shtml | archivedate = 5 January 2009 }} In 2006, Harrison ceremoniously rejected her "data collecting" methodologies and entered into a period of self-reflection and re-invention in order to develop a "healthier and more outward looking practice". The 2009 book about her work entitled ''Confessions of a Recovering Data Collector'', explores the negative impact such practices can have on individuals and wider society and includes her own "confession" that: "Web2.0 has spawned a whole new generation of data collectors. There is now such a ridiculous abundance of boring information about other people's lives on the internet, I felt obliged to stop adding to it". Harrison has since engaged in other activities that aim to draw attention to what she calls "the negative side effects of instantaneous ego-broadcasting"{{cite book | editor-last = Tolley | editor-first = Gail | date = 2010-12-03 | title = New Forms of Collectivity | url = http://issuu.com/centralstation/docs/centralstationbook | pages = 148–149 | location = Glasgow | publisher = Central Station | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} including launching her own ongoing "active Twitter boycott" in July 2008.{{cite web | url = https://twitter.com/ellieharrison | title = Ellie Harrison | date = 2008-07-01 | website = Twitter Boycott | publisher = Twitter | accessdate = 2014-05-01}} {{Promotion inline|date=January 2017}} == Recent work == Although she still retains a core interest in [[data visualization|data visualisation]], Harrison's recent work is more overtly political.{{cite journal | last = Herbert | first = Martin | date = 2011-05-01 | title = Profile: Ellie Harrison | url = http://www.ellieharrison.com/pdf/ellieharrison-profile.pdf | pages = 16–17 | journal = Art Monthly | location = London | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} She has used a mixture of sculpture, installation and live performance to respond to the British culture she grew up in and its dominant political and economic systems.{{cite web | url = http://www.vimeo.com/40723042 | title = Mixing It Up: An Intergenerational Perspective (Ellie Harrison & Jordan McKenzie in conversation) | date = 2012-04-23 | website = Artquest London | publisher = Vimeo | accessdate = 2014-10-01 }} Her all-night live performance ''General Election Drinking Game'' coincided with the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010]] in order to offer an alternative commentary on the results.{{cite news | last = Ronay | first = Barney | date = 2010-05-05 | title = Party Politics: Election Art | url = https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2010/may/05/election-diary-barney-ronay | newspaper = The Guardian | page = 17 | location = London & Manchester | publisher = Guardian News & Media | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} In 2011 her installation ''A Brief History of Privatisation'', which used a circle of electric massage chairs to re-enact the history of UK public service policy over the last century, was exhibited at [[Watermans Arts Centre]],{{cite web | url = https://www.watermans.org.uk/new-media-arts-archive/a-brief-history-of-privatisation-2011 | title = Exhibitions: A Brief History of Privatisation (2011) | date = 2011-03-11 | website = Watermans | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} [[Edinburgh Art Festival]]{{cite web | url = http://www.edinburghartfestival.com/2011/events/2011-08-09 | title = Detours: Josie Long at Inspace | date = 2011-08-09 | website = Edinburgh Art Festival | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} and Vane, Newcastle.{{cite web | url = http://vane.org.uk/past-exhibitions/market-forces | title = Market Forces | date = 2011-10-31 | website = Vane | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} She collaborated with British comedian [[Josie Long]] to create an alternative live "tour" of the exhibition.{{cite web | url = http://www.vimeo.com/studio14c/privatisation | title = A Brief History of Privatisation feat. Josie Long | date = 2011-10-31 | website = 14c Film | publisher = Vimeo | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} Harrison often uses deliberately playful and accessible techniques to animate what could otherwise be seen as dull or obscure economic information.{{cite web | url = http://www.dundee.ac.uk/djcad/staff/ellieharrison/ | title = Staff: Ellie Harrison | date = 2013-04-01 | website = Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art & Design | publisher = University of Dundee | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} Her 2009 installation ''The History of Financial Crises'', (first exhibited at Mejan Labs, Stockholm for Harrison's two-person show ''Transfers & Actions'' with [[Casey Reas]]{{cite web | url = http://www.mejanlabs.se/article_en.asp?ID=95&KAT=PREVEX&templ=1 | title = Transfers & Actions | date = 2009-04-15 | website = Mejan Labs | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }}), used a row of popcorn making machines to re-enact the history of capitalism over the last century. Harrison's ''Vending Machine'' (2009) has been exhibited at venues across the UK and Ireland and features an old vending machine reprogrammed (using an [[Arduino]] board controlled by a [[Pure Data]] patch) to release free crisps when search terms relating to the recession make the headlines on the BBC News RSS feed.{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/8586166.stm | title = Budget Buzzwords Prompted Machine to Deliver Crisps | date = 2010-03-24 | website = BBC News | publisher = BBC | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} It now features in the permanent public art collection at the [[Open Data Institute]], London.{{cite web | url = http://theodi.org/culture/vending-machine-2009 | title = Vending Machine (2009) Ellie Harrison | date = 2012-11-30 | website = Open Data Institute | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} In 2012, Harrison researched the history of UK public spending on the arts for ''The Redistribution of Wealth'', an interactive installation shown at [[Tate Britain]], London as part of the ''Late at Tate'' series.{{cite web | url = http://www.tate.org.uk/whats-on/tate-britain/music-and-live-performance/late-tate-britain-acts-legacy | title = Late at Tate Britain: Acts of Legacy | date = 2012-10-05 | website = Tate Britain | publisher = Tate | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} In 2014, she responded to the [[Scottish independence referendum, 2014|Referendum on Scottish Independence]] in the piece ''After the Revolution, Who Will Clean Up the Mess?'' at [[Talbot Rice Gallery]], Edinburgh. The installation featured a row of confetti cannons connected to a central detonation button, which would only be activated on the event of a "Yes" vote.{{cite news | last = Taylor | first = Rhona | date = 2014-07-31 | title = Confetti Cannon Primed to Explode, or Maybe Not | url = http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/uk/scotland/article4162752.ece?CMP=OTH-gnws-standard-2014_07_30 | newspaper = The Times | page = 16 | location = London | publisher = News Corp | accessdate = 2014-10-01 }}{{cite news | last = Unwin Jones | first = Sarah | date = 2014-08-09 | title = Getting Straight to the Point | url = http://www.heraldscotland.com/arts-ents/visual/counterpoint-talbot-rice-gallery-edinburgh.1407553206 | newspaper = The Herald Arts | page = 6 | location = Glasgow | publisher = Newsquest Media Group | accessdate = 2014-10-01 }} In January 2016, it was announced that Harrison had been given a grant of £15,000 by [[Creative Scotland]] for her project The Glasgow Effect, causing controversy on social media.{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-35232027 | title = Creative Scotland defends 'Glasgow Effect' arts project funding | date = 2016-01-05 | website = BBC News | publisher = BBC | accessdate = 2016-01-05 }}{{cite news | last = Hainey | first = Liam | date = 2016-01-06 | title = Outraged over a £15,000 Glasgow art project? Look at the bigger picture | url = https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/jan/06/glasgow-effect-art-project-ellie-harrison | newspaper = The Guardian | location = London & Manchester | publisher = Guardian News & Media | accessdate = 2016-01-07 }} == Activism == Harrison's growing interest in politics has increasingly moved her to direct political action, to the extent that her practice is now often described as "shifting between the roles of artist, activist and administrator".{{cite book |editor-last = Jeffrey |editor-first = Moira |date = 2014-07-22 |title = Generation: 25 Years of Contemporary Art in Scotland Guide |url = https://www.nationalgalleries.org/shop/online-shop/category/972/product/23940 |page = 195 |location = Edinburgh & Glasgow |publisher = National Galleries of Scotland & Glasgow Life |isbn = 978-1-906270-71-1 |accessdate = 2014-10-01 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141108110651/https://www.nationalgalleries.org/shop/online-shop/category/972/product/23940 |archivedate = 8 November 2014 |df = dmy-all }} Harrison began campaigning for the protection of public services in 2008 as one of the leaders of a successful campaign to "Save Victoria Baths" in Nottingham from closure,{{cite news | last = Palmer | first = Ed | date = 2008-06-05 | title = Saviours Become Surveyors | url = http://savevictoriabaths.ellieharrison.com/vb-pressnj2.pdf | newspaper = Nottingham & Trent Valley Journal | page = 8 | location = Nottingham | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} which resulted in [[Nottingham City Council]] committing £7 million to rebuild a new leisure centre on its existing site.{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/nottinghamshire/7303369.stm | title = Leisure Centre Gets £7m Promise | date = 2008-03-18 | website = BBC News | publisher = BBC | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} In 2009, whilst studying at [[Glasgow School of Art]], she began public transport campaigning by launching the ''Bring Back British Rail'' campaign.{{cite web | url = http://www.bringbackbritishrail.org/2009/07/campaign-history/ | title = Campaign History | date = 2009-07-29 | website = Bring Back British Rail | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} Motivated by her concerns about climate change and the need to encourage the use of less carbon-intensive transportation,{{cite journal | last = Harrison | first = Ellie | date = 2014-01-09 | title = Power For The People! | url = http://www.theecologist.org/blogs_and_comments/Blogs/2230013/power_for_the_people.html | journal = The Ecologist | location = London | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} she aimed to popularise the idea of returning Britain's rail network to public ownership, following its [[Privatisation of British Rail|privatisation in 1994]], when Harrison was 15 years old. Harrison has appeared on the Today programme,{{cite web | url = http://www.bringbackbritishrail.org/today | title = Today Programme | date = 2016-08-27 | website = Bring Back British Rail | accessdate = 2016-09-11 }} Sky News,{{cite web | url = http://www.vimeo.com/bringbackbritishrail/skynews | title = Sky News | date = 2012-08-16 | website = Bring Back British Rail | publisher = Vimeo | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} RT News{{cite web | url = http://www.vimeo.com/bringbackbritishrail/rtnews | title = RT News | date = 2015-01-05 | website = Bring Back British Rail | publisher = Vimeo | accessdate = 2015-01-09 }} and Russia Today,{{cite web | url = http://www.vimeo.com/bringbackbritishrail/goingunderground | title = Going Underground | date = 2014-01-06 | website = Bring Back British Rail | publisher = Vimeo | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} and on other national and local BBC Radio programmes as the campaign's spokesperson.{{cite web | url = http://www.bringbackbritishrail.org/media | title = Media Coverage | date = 2016-08-27 | website = Bring Back British Rail | accessdate = 2016-09-11 }} In 2013 she was invited by [[Caroline Lucas]] MP to sit on "The Future of Our Railways" panel at the annual conference of the [[Green Party of England and Wales]] in Brighton.{{cite web | url = http://www.vimeo.com/bringbackbritishrail/greenparty | title = Green Party Conference | date = 2013-09-16 | website = Bring Back British Rail | publisher = Vimeo | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} On 26 April 2015, less than six years after its launch, the Bring Back British Rail campaign reached a milestone of 100,000 supporters on its Facebook page.{{cite web | url = http://www.facebook.com/bringbackbritishrail/posts/10153180445911830/ | title = Campaign Reaches 100,000 Likes | date = 2015-04-26 | website = Bring Back British Rail | publisher = Facebook | accessdate = 2016-04-01 }} Later that year, after [[Jeremy Corbyn]] was elected leader of the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]], rail re-nationalisation became the [[Her Majesty's Most Loyal Opposition (United Kingdom)|Official Opposition]] policy.{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-34389319 | title = Labour conference: Rail nationalisation now official policy | date = 2015-09-29 | website = BBC News | publisher = BBC | accessdate = 2016-04-01 }} In 2013, Harrison led the "Say NO to Tesco in Scotland" campaign, which began as a protest against the proliferation of small supermarkets in the West end of [[Glasgow]].{{cite news | last = Roger | first = Hannah | date = 2013-06-10 | title = Campaigners Hit Out at Plan For Tesco Store in West End | url = http://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/news/campaigners-hit-out-at-plan-for-tesco-store-in-west-end-126769n.21249913 | page = 19 | newspaper = Evening Times | location = Glasgow | publisher = Newsquest | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} The campaign group presented a petition to "stop supermarket expansion on local high streets" to the Public Petitions Committee at the [[Scottish Parliament]] in January 2014.{{cite web | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8RoDaMA8UKc#t=32m28s | title = Public Petitions Committee – Scottish Parliament: 28th January 2014 | date = 2014-01-28 | website = The Scottish Parliament | publisher = YouTube | accessdate = 2015-01-09 }} In September 2014, after hearing the petition on three further occasions, the Committee referred it to the Local Government & Regeneration Committee to be considered in the context the Community Empowerment (Scotland) Bill.{{cite web | url = http://www.scottish.parliament.uk/GettingInvolved/Petitions/saynototesco | title = Supermarket Expansion on Local High Streets | date = 2014-01-28 | website = The Scottish Parliament | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} In January 2015, due to falling sales and profit warnings in 2014, Tesco announced it was axing plans for eight new stores in Scotland{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-highlands-islands-30725122 | title = Eight Planned New Tesco Stores in Scotland Shelved | date = 2015-01-08 | website = BBC News | publisher = BBC | accessdate = 2015-01-09 }} and closing 43 of its smaller stores across the UK.{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-30712762 | title = Tesco to Close 43 Stores Despite Better Christmas Sales | date = 2015-01-08 | website = BBC News | publisher = BBC | accessdate = 2015-01-09 }} == National Museum of Roller Derby == As an exploration of bureaucratic processes, over the last few years Harrison has been involved in the setting-up and running of a number of experimental and fully functional organisations and institutions, including the ''National Museum of Roller Derby'' (NMRD), which she founded at [[Glasgow Women's Library]] in 2012.{{cite web | url = http://www.vimeo.com/ellieharrison/nmrd | title = National Museum of Roller Derby | date = 2012-06-12 | website = Ellie Harrison | publisher = Vimeo | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} Harrison first became involved in the sport of [[Roller derby|Women's Flat Track Roller Derby]] at the start of 2012, when she began training with [[Glasgow Roller Derby]] under the [[Derby name|skater name]] CH£AP SKATE 79.{{cite journal | last = McMurder | first = Moxie | date = 2012-09-01 | title = National Museum of Roller Derby | url = http://www.ellieharrison.com/pdf/nmrd-leadjammer.pdf | page = 14 | journal = Lead Jammer | location = London | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} This coincided with her time as artist in residence at [[Glasgow Women's Library]] as part of the ''21 Revolutions'' project, celebrating the twentieth anniversary of the library. On 14 June 2012 the NMRD was launched, by establishing the library the official home of the UK's first permanent archive of materials and ephemeral relating to this all-female, full-contact sport.{{cite book |last = Patrick |first = Adele |date = 2014-03-03 |title = 21 Revolutions |url = http://www.freightbooks.co.uk/21-revolutions.html |page = 149 |location = Glasgow |publisher = Glasgow Women's Library & Freight Books |isbn = 978-1-908754-44-8 |accessdate = 2014-05-01 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140621031513/http://freightbooks.co.uk/21-revolutions.html |archivedate = 21 June 2014 |df = dmy-all }} == Awards and recognition == In 2011, Harrison was shortlisted for the [[Dazed#Artist Award|Converse/Dazed Emerging Artists Award]] with the [[Whitechapel Gallery]], London alongside Gabriele Beveridge, Bruce Ingram, Samuel Levack & Jennifer Lewandowski and Richard Parry.{{cite journal | last = Teh | first = Terence | date = 2011-10-01 | title = The Shortlist | url = http://www.dazeddigital.com/artsandculture/article/11570/1/converse-emerging-artists-award-ellie-harrison | pages = 122–125 | journal = Dazed & Confused | location = London | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} Later that year she was featured in ''The Hot 100'' – [[The List (magazine)]]'s "definitive list of Scottish creative talent"{{cite journal | last = Ensall | first = Jonny | date = 2011-12-06 | title = The Hot 100 2011 | url = http://www.list.co.uk/article/39372-the-hot-100-2011-100-50/ | pages = 24–25 | journal = The List | location = Edinburgh | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} and on [[The Independent on Sunday]]'s ''[[Pink List]]'' as "one to watch".{{cite news | last = Herbert | first = Ian | date = 2011-10-23 | title = The Pink List 2011 | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/the-ios-pink-list-2011-2374595.html | newspaper = Independent on Sunday | location = London | publisher = Independent Print Limited | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} In 2012, she was invited to be a member of the International Jury of the 6th [[Iris Prize]]{{cite web |url = http://www.irisprize.org/jury/year-2012/ |title = Jury 2012 |date = 2012-10-10 |website = Iris Prize |accessdate = 2014-05-01 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130110032049/http://www.irisprize.org/jury/year-2012/ |archivedate = 10 January 2013 |df = dmy }} and to co-host, with [[Peter Tatchell]], the awards ceremony for the inaugural Lush Prize in support of alternatives to animal testing.{{cite web | url = http://www.lushprize.org/past-years/2012-prize/2012-awards-ceremony/ | title = 2012 Awards Ceremony | date = 2012-11-15 | website = The Lush Prize | accessdate = 2014-05-01 }} In 2014, Harrison was shortlisted for the Best Artistic Response Award at the Climate Week Awards for her ongoing project ''Early Warning Signs''.{{cite web | url = http://www.climateweek.com/awards/climate-week-awards-2014/best-artistic-response/ | title = Best Artistic Response | date = 2014-03-04 | website = Climate Week Awards | accessdate = 2015-03-08 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150922064232/http://www.climateweek.com/awards/climate-week-awards-2014/best-artistic-response/ | archivedate = 22 September 2015 }} == Notable works == Below is a list of all Harrison's notable works * 2002 Eat 22 * 2003 Gold Card Adventures * 2005 Day-to-Day Data * 2005 Daily Data Logger * 2006 Tea Blog * 2009 Confessions of a Recovering Data Collector * 2009 Vending Machine * 2009 The History of Financial Crises * 2010 General Election Drinking Game * 2010 Press Release * 2011 A Brief History of Privatisation * 2011 Early Warning Signs{ * 2012 The Redistribution of Wealth * 2012 National Museum of Roller Derby * 2014 After the Revolution, Who Will Clean Up the Mess? * 2016 The Glasgow Effect == References == artists]] [[Category:Women conceptual artists]] [[Category:Women performance artists]] [[Category:Roller derby skaters]]

{{refimprove|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox ballet company | name = Full Radius Dance | logo = | local_name = | previous_names = Dance Force | predecessor = | founded = 1998 | founder = [[Douglas Scott (choreographer)|Douglas Scott]] | founders = | founding_director = [[Douglas Scott (choreographer)|Douglas Scott]] | founding_choreographers = | founding_person_type = | founding_person_name = | closed = | venue = ''7Stages Theatre''
1105 Euclid Ave NE
Atlanta, GA 30307 | website = {{URL|fullradiusdance.org}} | chief_executive = | executive director = | director = | assistant_director = | coordinator = | company_manager = | ballet_staff_type = | ballet_staff_name = | artistic_director = | associate_artistic_director = | deputy_director = | ballet_master_in_chief = | ballet_mistress = | ballet_master = | music_director = | principal_conductor = | choreographers = | artistic_staff_type = | artistic_staff_name = | parent_company = | sister_company = | orchestra = | official_school = | associated_schools = | formation = Formed out of the merger between '''Dance Force''' and '''E=Motion''' dance companies }} '''Full Radius Dance''' is a professional [[modern dance]] company in the field of [[physically integrated dance]] based in [[Atlanta]]. The company features dancers with and without [[physical disability|physical disabilities]]. ==Founding== In 1990, founder [[Douglas Scott (choreographer)|Douglas Scott]] established Dance Force, a traditional modern dance company. He began teaching classes for people with disabilities in 1993 through a partnership with VSA Arts of Georgia, and in 1995 formed a sister company for dancers with disabilities called E=Motion. The companies formally merged to create Full Radius Dance in 1998. Douglas Scott continues to serve as Artistic and Executive Director. ==Work== Full Radius Dance has created more than 50 repertory works. The company produces two concerts in Atlanta each year, including the Modern Atlanta Dance Festival, performs in festivals, tours, and presents site-specific and community works. Critically acclaimed works choreographed by Artistic Director Douglas Scott include "Passione", "Crawl/Climb", "Touch",{{cite news |first=Chelsea |last=Thomas |title=Full Radius Dance premieres three contemporary works |url=http://www.danceinforma.com/USA_magazine/2013/01/20/full-radius-dance-premieres-three-contemporary-works/ |work=Dance Informa |date=2013-01-20 }} "Bar Songs",{{cite news |first=Emily |last=Yewell Volin |title=Full Radius Dance in Concert |url=http://www.danceinforma.com/USA_magazine/2011/01/23/full-radius-dance-in-concert/ |work=Dance Informa |date=2011-01-23 }} "It is four years ago and it is yesterday",{{cite news |first=Cynthia |last= Bond Perry |title=Review: Full Radius completes a patchwork quilt of inventive, and thoughtful, modern dance |url=http://www.artsatl.com/2014/01/review-full-radius-completes-patchwork-quilt-inventive-thoughtful-modern-dance/ |work= ArtsATL |date=2014-01-28 }} and "SNAPSHOT". The company's 25th anniversary concert "Silver" premiered in Atlanta, GA in March 2017 and was subsequently performed internationally at the Una Mirada Diferente Festival{{Cite news|url=https://es.usembassy.gov/es/full-radius-dance-difunde-la-danza-contemporanea-estadounidense-y-promueve-los-derechos-de-las-personas-con-discapacidad-en-madrid-y-valencia/|title=Full Radius Dance difunde la danza contemporánea estadounidense y promueve los derechos de las personas con discapacidad en Madrid y Valencia {{!}} Embajada de EE.UU. en España y Andorra|date=2017-05-30|work=Embajada de EE.UU. en España y Andorra|access-date=2018-04-18|language=es-ES}} in Madrid, Spain and in New York City at the Harlem School of the Arts. Their most recent production, 'Tapestry' was heralded as a masterwork by ArtsAtl{{Cite news|url=http://artsatl.com/review-full-radius-dance-defies-physical-limitations-create-masterpiece/|title=Full Radius Dance creates a "Tapestry" masterpiece|date=2018-03-13|work=ArtsATL|access-date=2018-04-18|language=en-US}}. ==Education== Full Radius Dance offers educational programs, masterclasses, and workshops for all ages. The company also offers professional training in physically integrated dance through apprenticeships,{{Cite web|url = https://fullradiusdance.org/discover/apprentice|title = Apprenticeships|date = 30 March 2015|accessdate = 30 March 2015|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} residencies, and a summer intensive.{{Cite web|url = https://fullradiusdance.org/intensive|title = Summer Intensive|date = 30 March 2015|accessdate = 30 March 2015|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} == Current configuration == The current touring company consists of seven professional dancers; McKenzie Beaverson - Joined in 2017{{Cite web|url=https://fullradiusdance.org/discover/bios/mckenzie|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Lindy Dannelly - Joined in 2010{{Cite web|title = Lindy Dannelly Bio|url = https://fullradiusdance.org/discover/bios/lindy|website = fullradiusdance.org|accessdate = 2015-11-20|date = 2015}} Mazon Diaz - Joined in 2016{{Cite web|url=https://fullradiusdance.org/discover/bios/mazon|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Shawn Evangelista - Joined in 2012{{Cite web|url=https://fullradiusdance.org/discover/bios/shawn|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Laurel Lawson - Joined in 2004{{Cite web|title = Laurel Lawson Bio|url = https://fullradiusdance.org/discover/bios/laurel|website = fullradiusdance.org|accessdate = 2015-11-20|date = 2015}} Rebekah Pleasant - Joined in 2015{{Cite web|title = Rebekah Pleasant Bio|url = https://fullradiusdance.org/discover/bios/rebekah|website = fullradiusdance.org|accessdate = 2015-11-20|date = 2015}} Demarco Sleeper - Joined in 2017{{Cite web|url=https://fullradiusdance.org/discover/bios/demarco|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} ==The Modern Atlanta Dance Festival== Full Radius Dance is the host company of the Modern Atlanta Dance (MAD) Festival. A juried festival, MAD was created in 1995 to present and celebrate the best of Georgia's diverse modern and contemporary dance scene. The MAD Festival is currently presented as two nights of performances. Also under the umbrella of the festival are events such as the 24-hour dance festival and the Pioneer of Atlanta Dance award. The 24-hour dance festival is a project in which choreographers and dancers are locked in studios for 24 hours to create work. At the end of the 24-hour period, all of these works are presented and then the top two pieces perform their newly created works to open the core show.{{Cite web|title = The MAD Festival|url = https://fullradiusdance.org/experience/mad/about|website = fullradiusdance.org|accessdate = 2015-11-20|date = 2015}} The Pioneer of Atlanta Dance award commemorates an individual who has contributed to the regional dance community. Choreographer and modern dance pioneer Ruth Mitchell, former dancer for Jose Limon and Ruth Page and director of Ruth Mitchell Dance Company, was the inaugural recipient in 2015.{{Cite web|title = Preview: As it reaches its 21st year, Modern Atlanta Dance Festival offers a weekend of firsts|url = http://www.artsatl.com/2015/05/preview-reaches-21st-year-modern-atlanta-dance-festival-offers-weekend-firsts/|website = ArtsATL|date = 2015-05-20|accessdate = 2015-11-20|last = Shaw|first = Rachael|publication-date = 2015-05-20}} In 2016, the award was presented to Mozell Spriggs, founder of the Spelman College Dance Program. In 2017, it honored Bobby and Virginia Barnett. Lee Harper{{Cite web|url=http://leeharperanddancers.com/Lee_Harper_____.html|title=Lee Harper|website=leeharperanddancers.com|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}} is the recipient of the 2018 award. Over the past two decades, Full Radius Dance has presented more than 65 companies and independent choreographers, and paid over $30,000 in honorariums to MAD participants. Entering its 24th year, the upcoming festival will be held May 2018 at the Balzer Theatre at Herren's in downtown Atlanta.{{Cite web|url = https://fullradiusdance.org/experience/mad/about|title = The MAD Festival|date = 30 March 2015|accessdate = 30 March 2015|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} ==References== ==External links== {{Portal| Dance | Disability }} * [http://www.fullradiusdance.org/ Full Radius Dance website] * [http://www.nchpad.org/919/5041/Physically~Integrated~Dance~and~Full~Radius~Dance~Company NCHPAD: Physically Integrated Dance and Full Radius Dance Company] {{DEFAULTSORT:Full Radius Dance}} [[Category:Dance companies in the United States]] [[Category:Dance education in the United States]] [[Category:Modern dance companies]] [[Category:Contemporary dance companies]] [[Category:Physically integrated dance]] [[Category:Dance in Georgia (U.S. state)]]

revision.text:
The '''Handicraft Guild''' was an organization central to [[Arts and Crafts movement]] active in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota|Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]], United States, from 1904 to 1918. The Handicraft guild was founded, led, and staffed primarily by women, making it historically significant to women's art movements nationwide.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cartwright|first=R. L.|title=Handicraft Guild|url=http://www.mnopedia.org/group/handicraft-guild|work=[[MNopedia]]|publisher=Minnesota Historical Society|date=March 1, 2012}}</ref>
In addition to creating stone and metal art works, the Guild was an egalitarian school with the mission "[to] give authoritative instruction in design and its solution in terms of materials; also to furnish complete training for students desirous of becoming Craftsmen, Designers and Teachers." Its pupils included [[Grant Wood]].<ref>{{cite book | last =Conforti | first =Michael | title =Art and Life on the Upper Mississippi 1890-1915: Minnesota 1900 (The Ameridan Arts) | publisher =University of Delaware Press | date =June 1994 | pages =333 | isbn = 0-87413-560-5 }}</ref>
The Handicraft Guild was revived after the turn of the 21st century and is a leading influence on the [[Arts in Minneapolis]].
The [[Handicraft Guild Building]] is located at 89 10th Street South, Minneapolis, Minnesota and still stands today thanks to the efforts of the [[Minneapolis Heritage Preservation Commission]].
Correspondence, photographs, and general research about topics, organizations, and individuals involved in or associated with the Handicraft Guild of Minneapolis are held by the [[Minnesota Historical Society]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Marcia G Anderson Handicraft Guild of Minneapolis research files|url=http://www.mnhs.org/library/findaids/00999.xml|publisher=Minnesota Historical Society|accessdate=February 26, 2014}}</ref>
==External links== * [http://www.ci.minneapolis.mn.us/hpc/landmarks/hpc_landmarks_10th_st_s_89-91_handicraft_guild_building The Handicraft Guild Building - Minneapolis Heritage Preservation Commission] * [http://www.placeography.org/index.php/Handicraft_Guild%2C_89-91_10th_Street_South%2C_Minneapolis%2C_Minnesota Handicraft Guild on Placeography.org] * [https://bridgingmpls.wordpress.com/2015/05/16/first/ Slideshow - What does it look like?] * [http://www.placeography.org/index.php/Handicraft_Guild_Addition%2C_1004_Marquette_Avenue%2C_Minneapolis%2C_Minnesota Handicraft Guild Addition on Placeography.org] * [https://bridgingmpls.wordpress.com/2015/05/16/1004-marquette-the-handicraft-guild-addtion/ Slideshow -What does it look like?] * [http://www.thehandicraftguild.instapage.com/ The Handicraft Guild Art Collective 2015] * [http://www.minneapolismn.gov/www/groups/public/@cped/documents/webcontent/wcms1p-141313.pdf Development proposal 2015]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Hereafter | image = Hereafter.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Clint Eastwood]] | producer = Clint Eastwood
[[Kathleen Kennedy (producer)|Kathleen Kennedy]]
[[Robert Lorenz]] | writer = [[Peter Morgan]] | starring = [[Matt Damon]]
[[Cécile de France]] | music = Clint Eastwood | cinematography = [[Tom Stern (cinematographer)|Tom Stern]] | editing = [[Joel Cox]]
[[Gary D. Roach]] | studio = [[The Kennedy/Marshall Company]]
[[Malpaso Productions]]
[[Amblin Entertainment]] (credit only) | distributor = [[Warner Bros.|Warner Bros. Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2010|09|12|[[Toronto International Film Festival|TIFF]]|2010|10|22|United States}} | runtime = 129 minutes | country = United States | language = English
French | budget = $50 million{{cite news |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/entertainmentnewsbuzz/2010/10/movie-projector-paranormal-activity-2-looking-to-scare-jackass-3-d-out-of-the-top-spot.html |title=Movie projector: 'Paranormal Activity 2' looking to scare 'Jackass 3-D' out of the top spot |last=Fritz |first=Ben |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |publisher=[[Tribune Company]] |date=October 21, 2010 |accessdate=October 21, 2010}} | gross = $105.2 million{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=hereafter.htm|title=Hereafter (2010) - Box Office Mojo|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=February 17, 2011}} }} '''''Hereafter''''' is a 2010 American [[fantasy]] [[drama film]] directed, co-produced, and scored by [[Clint Eastwood]], written by [[Peter Morgan]], and executive produced by [[Steven Spielberg]]. The film tells three parallel stories about three people affected by death in similar ways{{mdash}}all three have issues of communicating with the dead; [[Matt Damon]] plays American factory worker George, who is able to communicate with the dead and who has worked professionally as a [[Clairvoyance|clairvoyant]], but no longer wants to communicate with the dead; [[Cécile de France]] plays French television journalist Marie, who survives a [[near-death experience]] during the [[2004 Indian Ocean tsunami]]; and British twins Marcus and Jason (played by [[Frankie and George McLaren]]). [[Bryce Dallas Howard]], [[Lyndsey Marshal]], [[Jay Mohr]], and [[Thierry Neuvic]] have supporting roles. Morgan sold the script [[Spec script|on spec]] to [[DreamWorks]] in 2008, but it transferred to [[Warner Bros.]] by the time Eastwood (who has a long-standing relationship with Warner Bros.) had signed on to direct in 2009. Principal photography ran from October 2009 to February 2010 on locations in [[London]], [[San Francisco]], [[Paris]], and [[Hawaii]]. ''Hereafter'' premiered as a "Special Presentation" at the [[2010 Toronto International Film Festival]] on September 12, 2010. The film was given a [[limited release]] on October 15, 2010 and was released across North America on October 22, 2010. Although a box office success, the film received mixed reviews, with critics praising the plot and acting performances, while noting that the movie suffered from a lack of focus on the story. ==Plot== {{Plot|film|date=March 2018}} On assignment in India, French television journalist Marie Lelay is shopping for souvenirs for her lover Didier's children. She finds a stand where a mother and her daughter work; they sell gifts to Marie for a dollar. Didier looks over the balcony and witnesses the [[2004 Indian Ocean tsunami]] coming into shore. It hits as Marie watches from a distance. She grabs hold of the girl and runs away from the shore but is quickly swallowed by the wave. Pulled lifeless from the water, she is resuscitated by rescuers but is left for dead. She gasps back to life after having a [[Near death experience|near-death experience]] in which she sees a vision of human figures inhabiting a realm of light, among them the silhouettes of the mother and daughter holding hands. Marie and Didier are soon reunited as the disaster subsides and they return to Paris. Marie's experience, however, interferes with her work performance to the point that Didier (who is also her producer) sends her on a leave of absence to write the book they've discussed, which would add to her prestige. In San Francisco, former professional psychic George Lonegan is persuaded against his wishes to perform a reading for Christos, a wealthy client of his brother Billy. A genuine [[Mediumship|medium]] with a gift for communicating with the dead, George abandoned his old career because he was unable to deal with the emotional impact of the reunions and the often disturbingly intimate family secrets revealed. While doing the reading, George hears the word June and asks if a date in June means anything to him. Christos at first denies that it means anything, but privately reveals to Billy that June was the name of his late wife's nurse, whom he was in love with for ten years. In London, 12-year-old twins Jason and Marcus try desperately to prevent their alcoholic, heroin-addicted mother, Jackie, from losing them to social services. After evading the authorities yet again, the boys' mother sends Jason to the [[chemist]] to pick up her detox prescription, having finally decided to get clean. On the way home, Jason is attacked by street thugs, and while trying to escape, he is hit by a van and killed. No longer able to protect his mother, and barely able to cope with life without the brother he idolizes, Marcus is sent to a foster home. Now writing a book and with more time to contemplate her near-death experience, Marie travels to Switzerland to meet a renowned specialist in the field. As the director of a hospice who has seen her share of dying patients, the doctor describes herself as a former skeptic who was convinced by the evidence that the afterlife exists and that people like Marie have had a genuine view of it. She persuades Marie to write a book on her experience in the hope that the scientific community will ultimately accept the reality of life beyond death. Desperate for one last reunion with his twin brother, Marcus steals money from his foster parents and goes around London seeking someone to help him contact Jason. He encounters only frauds and pretenders. While he is trying to board the underground at [[Charing Cross]], Jason's cap, which has become a talisman for Marcus, blows off his head. Delayed by trying to find the cap, he misses his train and sees it explode in the tunnel during the [[7 July 2005 London bombings|2005 London Bombings]]. George enrolls in a cooking class taught by one of San Francisco's leading chefs. Its students are paired-up, resulting in George being partnered with a young woman named Melanie. The two hit it off and after attending their second class decide to put their new culinary skills to use by preparing an Italian dinner at George's place. All goes well until they hear an ill-timed phone message from his brother, which inclines George to reveal his past as a psychic to Melanie. Curious, she presses George to do a reading for her. George explains his reluctance, but acquiesces. They contact the spirit of Melanie's father, who ends the session by asking her forgiveness for what he did to her as a child. Melanie flees George's home in tears, and she doesn't return to the cooking class. Having been in talks with a publisher before her trip to Thailand about a biography of [[François Mitterrand]], Marie now stuns them with her new manuscript entitled "''Hereafter: A Conspiracy of Silence''". The publisher rejects the manuscript but soon steers her toward other publishers who might be interested, the most promising of them in London. Marie learns from Didier that he does not intend on having her back at the job he urged her to take leave of, because her public interest in the hereafter damages her reputation as a serious journalist, and that he is having an affair with the woman who replaced her on the TV news program. George is laid off from his factory job, and is persuaded by Billy to revive his psychic practice. Still heartbroken over the fiasco with Melanie, he changes his mind and impulsively leaves San Francisco to make a new start elsewhere. He travels to London and listens every night to audiobook readings by [[Derek Jacobi]] of [[Charles Dickens]]' works. As a Dickens devotee, he also visits the Dickens Museum and attends Jacobi's live reading of Dickens at the [[London Book Fair]]. There, one of the presenters is Marie, reading her now published book, ''Hereafter''. While handing a signed copy of her book to George, their hands touch and George has a psychic flash of Marie's tsunami drowning. Marcus and his foster parents are also at the London Book Fair. Asking leave of them, Marcus spots George, someone he has read about and seen online. Marcus attempts to speak with the medium, who brushes him off and returns to his hotel. Marcus follows him, standing outside the hotel until nightfall. Eventually George asks him in and agrees to do his reading. Through George, Jason tells Marcus that he is happy in the afterlife. He instructs Marcus to stop wearing his cap and says it was he who knocked it off his head at the train station. It was used, he says, to keep Marcus from the doomed train but now he must stand on his own. Jason tells him not to fear this "because we are one". As Marcus leaves George, he says he is sorry about "the French woman" as he could tell that "you like her." The last time we see Marcus, he is visiting his mother in a rehab center. She is visibly better and he is not wearing Jason's cap. Marcus lets George know where Marie is staying. George leaves an anonymous note for Marie, saying he believes her book to be true. She decides to join the anonymous fan for lunch and discovers George. While she is looking for him, George sees a vision of them kissing at the same meeting. Their shared glimpses of the hereafter having made them appreciate this life all the more, George and Marie sit together in the cafe. ==Cast== [[File:NYFF 2010 "Hereafter" Press Conference.jpg|thumb|300px|NYFF 2010 "Hereafter" Press Conference]] * [[Matt Damon]] as George Lonegan, an American factory worker and "a reluctant [[psychic]] [...] who can speak to the dead but prefers not to".Random House (undated). The original ''Hereafter'' production schedule clashed with Damon's filming commitments to ''[[The Adjustment Bureau]]'', so he emailed Eastwood, suggesting that the director recast the role of George for either [[Christian Bale]], [[Casey Affleck]], [[Hayden Christensen]] or [[Josh Brolin]]. Instead, Eastwood altered the filming schedule to accommodate Damon, and the actor was able to complete both films. * [[Cécile de France]] as Marie Lelay, a French television journalist who survives a [[tsunami]].Dawtrey, Adam (October 20, 2009). At the beginning of the film, Frankie McLaren plays the role of Jason, and George McLaren plays the role of Marcus; then both play Marcus alternately. Jason is killed in a car accident early in the film, and Marcus later attempts to contact him in the afterlife. The deal was reportedly worth a "low-seven-figure advance".Fleming, Michael (March 27, 2008). "[http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117983073.html?categoryid=1236&cs=1 DreamWorks takes 'Hereafter']". ''Variety'' (Reed Business Information). Retrieved on November 19, 2008. Executive producer [[Steven Spielberg]] was initially concerned that the low-key ending to the script would put audiences off the film, so Morgan rewrote it to be grander. However, subsequent drafts restored the original ending.Boucher Geoff (September 9, 2010). "[http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/music/la-et-clint-eastwood-20100909,0,7943805.story With 'Hereafter,' Clint Eastwood contemplates what's next]". ''The Los Angeles Times'' (Tribune Company). Retrieved on September 11, 2010. Following its split from [[Paramount Pictures]], DreamWorks retained the script, and began talks with Clint Eastwood to direct. Eastwood was signed on in November 2008.Siegel, Tatiana (November 13, 2008). "[http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117995852.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 Eastwood, Spielberg talking thriller]". ''Variety'' (Reed Business Information). Retrieved on November 19, 2008. By the time of Matt Damon's casting in 2009, the script was being developed under the supervision of Eastwood's [[Malpaso Productions]] for [[Warner Bros.]]. Eastwood was attracted to the script because he was keen to direct a supernatural thriller, and liked how Morgan incorporated real-world events into fiction. Eastwood told ''[[LA Weekly]]'', "There's a certain charlatan aspect to the hereafter, to those who prey on people's beliefs that there's some afterlife, and mankind doesn't seem to be willing to accept that this is your life and you should do the best you can with it and enjoy it while you’re here, and that'll be enough. There has to be immortality or eternal life and embracing some religious thing. I don't have the answer. Maybe there is a hereafter, but I don't know, so I approach it by not knowing. I just tell the story."Foundas, Scott (December 10, 2009). "[http://www.laweekly.com/2009-12-10/film-tv/eastwood-on-the-pitch/4 Eastwood On The Pitch]". ''LA Weekly'' (Village Voice Media). Retrieved on January 11, 2010. Production was based in the [[United Kingdom]], due to tax incentives and funding from the [[UK Film Council]], though filming locations spanned three countries.Turner, Mimi (August 9, 2010). "[http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/world/news/e3i829ad7a89f41e337d1aa092d696a8397 Eastwood urges rethink over U.K. Film Council]". Filming commenced in [[France]] on October 19, 2009. A days filming was done at the old Belle Epoque, Le Grand Hôtel-Restaurant du Montenvers, in the village of Planet, near [[Chamonix]]. The hotel building was transformed into a Swiss hospice for scenes between Cécile de France and [[Marthe Keller]]. A cordon was set up around the area to prevent local residents and paparazzi taking photographs of the set, though the mayor of Chamonix was allowed through for a brief meeting with Eastwood.Chandellier, Antoine; Emmanuelle Duffeal (October 20, 2009). "[http://www.ledauphine.com/chamonixun-hospice-quelqu-@/index.jspz?article=209741 Les confidences de Clint Eastwood sur le tournage]" (in French). ''Le Dauphiné Libéré''. Retrieved on November 11, 2009. Production then moved to Paris for four days. On October 21, a short scene between de France and [[Mylène Jampanoï]] was filmed in a stairwell inside the [[France Télévisions]] building.Staff (October 22, 2009). Premiere (Groupe Lagardere). Retrieved on November 17, 2009. Scenes were also filmed in an auditorium at [[Red Lion Square]] and at [[Camberwell Cemeteries|Camberwell New Cemetery]].[http://filmlondon.org.uk/filming_in_london/locations_crew_facilities/locations/location_of_the_month/november2010 Film London, Guide to filming in London, November 2010, Camberwell New Cemetery] The room was redressed to represent a fictional Center For Psychic Advancement, which the Marcus character visits. After these scenes were shot, production was halted, as Matt Damon was working on another film.Belloni, Matthew; Stephen Galloway (November 30, 2009). "[http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/film/news/e3icc2aee71977fdb172f6d373908310909 Clint Eastwood: The elder statesman]". ''The Hollywood Reporter'' (Nielsen Business Media). Retrieved on December 5, 2009. Filming resumed on January 12, 2010; Eastwood filmed scenes with de France for three days on the Hawaiian island of [[Maui]]. On the first day, scenes were filmed in the lobby and guest rooms of the Sheraton Maui Resort & Spa in [[Kaanapali, Hawaii|Kaanapali]].Tracy, Carla (January 14, 2010). "[http://www.mauinews.com/page/content.detail/id/527633.html?nav=5037 West side stories...]". ''The Maui News''. Retrieved on January 24, 2010. On January 13, scenes were filmed on Front Street in [[Lahaina, Hawaii|Lahaina]]. A hundred crew worked on the scenes.Chatenever, Rick (December 8, 2009). "[http://www.mauinews.com/page/content.detail/id/526515.html?nav=10 Eastwood to shoot scenes on Maui]". ''The Maui News''. Retrieved on December 8, 2009.Vieth, Mark (December 31, 2009). ''Lahaina News''. Retrieved on January 2, 2010. The location managers were given permission by Lahaina authorities to close a small section of the street in order to film scenes depicting "an unnamed, South Pacific-type outdoor marketplace, complete with outdoor shopping stalls and street vendors". The location manager explained to the ''Lahaina News'', "Front Street's proximity to the water and the architecture of its buildings help supply a look that will require much less transformation towards this goal than other locations which were under consideration". The street was closed off to vehicles on the evening of January 12. The scene—the first scene of the film—depicts Cécile de France's character coming out of her hotel just as a tsunami hits the island. The aftermath of the tsunami was filmed on January 14 at a property in [[Kapalua, Hawaii|Kapalua]]. Chatenever, Rick (January 12, 2010). "[http://www.mauinews.com/page/content.detail/id/527571.html Hereafter's' Maui scenes begin filming]". ''The Maui News''. Retrieved on January 12, 2010. Production next moved to the [[San Francisco Bay Area]]. On January 19, scenes featuring Damon were shot at the [[California and Hawaiian Sugar Company]] refinery in [[Crockett, California]], and the exterior of C&H Sugar is seen on screen. Visual effects work was carried out by Los Angeles-based [[Scanline VFX]]. 169 effects were created, the key sequence of which was the tsunami, which features "full CG water shots and CG water extensions to water plates, digital doubles, CG set extensions, matte paintings, digital make-up fx and full CG environments with extensive destruction, from toppling digital palm trees to colliding digital cars".Desowitz, Bill (August 27, 2010). The film was given a limited release on October 15, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/blogs/popcornbiz/This-Weeks-New-Movies--104912674.html|title = This Week's Movies: Seeing "RED"? Or Will You "Hereafter" Be a "Jackass"? | NBC Philadelphia|date =October 15, 2010|author =Ross, Scott|publisher = [[NBC Universal]]|accessdate = 16 October 2010}} The film premiered in Japan on February 19, 2011.{{cite web| title= Eastwood's latest is a matter of life and death|url= http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/ff20110218a1.html | publisher = [[The Japan Times]] |date= February 18, 2011 | accessdate=2011-03-16}} A few days after the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|11 March 2011 earthquake and tsunami in Japan]], the film was withdrawn from all cinemas in that country, two weeks earlier than originally planned. "[[Warner Bros.]] spokesperson Satoru Otani said the film's terrifying tsunami scenes were 'not appropriate' at this time."{{cite news| title= Clint Eastwood film ''Hereafter'' is pulled from Japan| url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-12743949 | publisher= [[BBC News]] | date= 15 March 2011 | accessdate=2011-03-16}} ===Critical reception=== ''Hereafter'' has received mixed reviews from critics. Review aggregate [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reports that 46% of critics - though 59% of "top critics - have given the film a positive review based on 217 reviews, with an average score of 5.7 out of 10. The critical consensus is: "Despite a thought-provoking premise and Clint Eastwood's typical flair as director, ''Hereafter'' fails to generate much compelling drama, straddling the line between poignant sentimentality and hokey tedium." {{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/hereafter/|title=Hereafter Movie Reviews, Pictures - Rotten Tomatoes|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=October 30, 2010}} [[Metacritic]], another review aggregator, assigned the film a weighted average score of 56/100 based on 41 reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/hereafter|title=Hereafter Reviews, Ratings, Credits, and More at Metacritic|work=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=October 30, 2010}} [[Roger Ebert]], however, gave the film four stars (out of four), calling it a film that "considers the idea of an afterlife with tenderness, beauty and a gentle tact. I was surprised to find it enthralling."{{cite news|url= http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20101019/REVIEWS/101019979|accessdate= 2011-03-10| publisher=suntimes.com| title=Hereafter | first=Roger | last=Ebert| authorlink= Roger Ebert| date=October 19, 2010}} The film received a nomination for the [[Academy Award for Best Visual Effects]], but lost to another Warner Bros. film, ''[[Inception]]''. It won the [[Visual Effects Society]] Award for [[Visual Effects Society Award for Outstanding Supporting Visual Effects in a Feature Motion Picture|Outstanding Supporting Visual Effects in a Feature Motion Picture]] and was also nominated in the category of Outstanding Compositing in a Feature Motion Picture.{{cite web|url=https://www.visualeffectssociety.com/ayear/9th-annual-ves-awards|title=9th revision.comment: repaired link(s) to disambiguation pages ([[WP:DPL|you can help]]) - Rusumo
revision.text:
[[File:Fresque Imigongo-Festival international de géographie 2011 (2).jpg|thumb|''Imigongo'' art on display at the International Geography Festival in [[Saint-Dié-des-Vosges]], France]] {{Expand French|date=January 2016}} '''Imigongo''' ({{IPA-rw|imiɡoːŋɡo|Kinyarwanda:}}) is an [[art form]] popular in [[Rwanda]] traditionally made by women using [[cow dung]]. Often in the colors black, white and red, popular themes include spiral and geometric designs that are painted on walls, pottery, and canvas.
The images are produced using cow dung which is put onto wooden boards in spiral and geometric designs. The dung is left to harden and is then decorated using colours made from organic material. The traditional colours are black, white, red, grey and beige-yellow but increasingly other colours are used.
The imigongo images were originally found in [[Kibungo]] inside the walls of huts as "magical" decorations during the 18th century.
During the 1994 [[Rwandan Genocide|Genocide]] the skills involved almost disappeared. However, a women's cooperative on the road to [[Rusumo, Rwanda|Rusumo]] in the [[Eastern Province, Rwanda|Eastern Province]] near [[Kirehe]] has rescued and revived this uniquely Rwandan art form. Traditionally geometric designs are produced but as the women artists have grown in confidence they have begun to experiment with more modern, innovative images that convey the spirit of the Rwandan landscape, its flora and fauna and its people.
==External links== *"[http://jpughinrwanda.blogspot.com/2011/06/more-about-imigongo.html More about Imigongo]", ''John Pugh in Rwanda''. *"[http://www.access-rwanda-safaris.com/rwanda-info/art-of-imigongo/ Art of Imigongo]", ''Access Rwanda Safaris''.
[[Category:Rwandan culture]] [[Category:African art]]
{{Commonscat|Imigongo}}

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=March 2018}} {{unreferenced|date=December 2017}} }}
{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2017}}
{{Infobox artist | name = Israel Painters and Sculptors Association | image = | imagesize = | caption = Israel Painters and Sculptors Association | birth_date = 1934 | birth_place = Israel | nationality = Israel | field = Painting and sculpting | movement =[[Israeli art]] }}
'''The Israel Painters and Sculptors Association''' was established in 1934 and has been associated with many painters and sculptors who worked in Israel. With the establishment of the State of Israel, the name of the association was changed to the "Association of Painters and Sculptors in Israel". In 2002, the name was changed again to "Painters and Sculptors Association ([[Tel Aviv]])" and three independent associations of painters and sculptors were established in [[Jerusalem Artists House|Jerusalem]], Haifa and Be'er Sheva.
== Hebrew Artists Association == The association was founded in October 1920 by the Association of Hebrew Artists, in its committee were the following artists: Meir Gur-Arie, S. Ben-David, [[Abel Pann]], Avraham Melnikov and Shmuel Opel. The aim of the association was to "develop and disseminate among the people the arts, the art work and taste and beauty in the Hebrew spirit." In April 1921 the members of the association presented an exhibition at the [[Tower of David]].
Since 1923, the association has exhibited 19 different group exhibitions. These were eclectic exhibitions with many works of art on various artistic levels. Alongside these exhibitions, occasional group exhibitions were held on a commercial or artistic basis.
In addition, the Society created the Painting and Sculpture Section of the journal "Theater and Art" which was published in 1927.
== Association of Painters and Sculptors == On August 4, 1934, the first convention of the Association of Painters and Sculptors was held in Tel Aviv. There was talk about building a pavilion for exhibitions and a permanent exhibition, establishing a cooperative of painters, a club, mutual help and housing for the members of the association. A committee was chosen, composed of [[Chaim Gliksberg]], [[Nahum Gutman]], Newman, Avni, Yishai Kolbiansky, Leoben and Eliahu Sigard. Gliksberg was the association secretary. On August 14, a parallel assembly was held in Jerusalem, in which a committee was appointed that included [[Zeev Ben Zvi]], Meir Gur-Arie and [[Jacob Steinhardt]].
One of the association's exhibitions, "The Eighth Exhibition," took place in December 1942 at [[Habima Theatre]], where the works of [[Arie Aroch]], Aharon Giladi, Zvi Meirovitch, Avraham Natan (Nathanson), [[Avigdor Stematsky]] and [[Yehezkel Streichman]] were exhibited. Another sculptor, [[Dov Feigin]] appeared in the catalog but did not participate in the exhibition at last. Another exhibition – "The Shiva Exhibition" – took place in 1947 at the [[Tel Aviv Museum]], with the participation of Aroch, Giladi, Meirovitch, Natan, Streichman, Jacob Wexler and [[Yosef Zaritsky]]. In these exhibitions, the artists aspired to the creation of modern art under European influence and to create "an original style, rooted in our reality." In these exhibitions, although they did not establish a clear artistic platform, there was a tendency to emphasize the painterly means. In addition, these exhibitions symbolized a certain separation and a "positive appearance" of the artists against the background of the "generalism" regime ... which helps blur the boundaries and dimensions, in order to impose mediocrity "
In 1948,[[Yosef Zaritsky]] served as chairman of the association, and when an invitation came to present an exhibition of Israeli artists in the Italian pavilion at the [[Venice Biennale]], he chose not to share the list of participating artists because of his concern about the selection of medium-sized artists. In the wake of the accusations, several artists, including [[Moshe Castel]], Streichman and [[Yohanan Simon]], announced their immediate retirement from the association, and they established with Zaritsky the "[[Ofakim Hadashim]]".
From 1964 to 1967, [[Ruth Horam]] served as the chairperson of the Association
From 1969 to 1981, [[Alexander Bogen]] served as chairman of the Association.
In the years 1989–2005, Rachel Shavit-Bentwich served as chairperson of the Association and as Chairperson of the Honorary Council.
==Israel Painters and Sculptors Association Members (partial list)==
* [[Alima]] <ref>[http://gordongallery.co.il/artists/Default.aspx?p=223 Gordon Gallery]</ref> * Orna Lutski, since 1996 <ref>[http://www.ornalutski.co.il/israeli.htm]</ref> * [[Zvi Yehuda Aldouby]] <ref>[http://museum.imj.org.il/artcenter The Information Center for Israeli Art, The Israel Museum, Jerusalem]</ref> * Ora Lahav Chaaltiel <ref>[http://museum.imj.org.il/artcenter The Information Center for Israeli Art, The Israel Museum, Jerusalem]</ref> * Abraham Hasak, since 1959 <ref>[http://museum.imj.org.il/artcenter The Information Center for Israeli Art, The Israel Museum, Jerusalem]</ref> * Moshe Kassirer, since 2008 <ref>[https://www.kassirer.co.il/english Artist website]</ref> * Fain Maureen, since 1990 <ref>[http://www.art.org.il/?jerusalem-artists=fain-maureen&lang=en&lang=en Jerusalem Artists House]</ref> * [[Gad Ullman]] <ref>[http://museum.imj.org.il/artcenter/newsite/en/?artist=Ullman,%20Gad&list=U The Information Center for Israeli Art, The Israel Museum, Jerusalem]</ref> (see Hebrew [[:he:גד אולמן|Gad Ullman]]) * Arie Wachenhauser, since 1962 <ref>[http://museum.imj.org.il/artcenter The Information Center for Israeli Art, The Israel Museum, Jerusalem]</ref>
==See also== [[Visual arts in Israel]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.culture.org.il/directory/viewItem.asp?cat=3&subcat=3.1&idNum=7927 Israel Arts Directory]
{{Authority control}}

There is a wide range of ways in which people have represented '''[[Khojaly Massacre]] in popular culture'''.
There have also been numerous [[Khojaly Massacre Memorials|memorials of the massacre]] around the world.
==Literature== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Book name ! Author ! Notes |- | 2013 | ''Genocide Almanax'' | Ireli Public Union | <ref>{{cite web|title=В Баку состоится презентация книги Genocide Almanax |url=http://www.1news.az/society/20131104043730197.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20131105040438/http://www.1news.az/society/20131104043730197.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 November 2013 |work=1news.az |accessdate=5 November 2013 |language=Russian }}</ref> |- | 2011 | ''Peacemaking: From Practice to Theory'' | Susan Allen Nan, Andrea Bartoli and Zachariah Cherian Mampilly | <ref name=bookx>{{cite web|title=Peacemaking: From Practice to Theory |url=http://www.khojaly.org/peacemaking-from-practice-to-theory/ |work=khojaly.org |accessdate=5 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105051925/http://www.khojaly.org/peacemaking-from-practice-to-theory/ |archivedate= 5 November 2013 |df= }}</ref> |- | 2011 | ''The Khojaly Trauma and Mutalibov’s Fall'' | [[Svante Cornell]] | <ref name=bookx /> |- | 2010 | ''The Caucasus: An Introduction'' | [[Thomas de Waal]] | <ref>{{cite web|title=The Caucasus: An Introduction|url=https://www.amazon.com/The-Caucasus-Introduction-Thomas-Waal/dp/0195399773|work=www.amazon.com|accessdate=5 November 2013}}</ref> |- | 2004 | ''[[Black Garden: Armenia and Azerbaijan Through Peace and War]]'' | [[Thomas de Waal]] | |- | 2000 | ''Azerbaijan: A Quest for Identity'' | [[Charles van der Leeuw]] | Part of ''Caucasus World'' series.<ref>{{cite web|title=Azerbaijan: A Quest for Identity|url=https://www.amazon.com/Azerbaijan-Quest-Identity-Caucasus-World/dp/0312219032|work=www.amazon.com|accessdate=5 November 2013}}</ref> |- | 2000 | ''Small Nations and Great Powers: A Study of Ethnopolitical Conflict in the Caucasus'' | [[Svante Cornell]] | Part of ''Caucasus World'' series.<ref>{{cite web|title=Azerbaijan: A Quest for Identity|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Small-Nations-Great-Powers-Ethnopolitical/dp/0700711627/ref=sr_1_11?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1383624108&sr=1-11&keywords=khojaly|work=www.amazon.com|accessdate=5 November 2013}}</ref> |- | 1992 | ''Eyewitness Account From the Following Day'' | [[Thomas Goltz]] | <ref>{{cite web|title=Eyewitness Account From the Following Day (1992)|url=http://www.azer.com/aiweb/categories/magazine/ai101_folder/101_articles/101_goltz_article.html|publisher=azer.com|accessdate=5 November 2013}}</ref> |- | 1992 | ''Karabakh’s Bloody Maelstrom – A Cry for Khojaly'' | Yuri Pompeyev | <ref name=bookx /> |}
==Films== The first European film about the Khojaly Massacre appeared in 2012, named "Endless Corridor" was filmed by the Union of European Cinematographers within the framework of the project "Peaceful Caucasus" under director Richardas Lopaitis's management.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lithuanian war journalist puts his memories about Khojaly Massacre in a film|url=http://www.15min.lt/en/article/world/lithuanian-journalist-puts-his-memories-about-armenian-fascism-in-a-film-529-201042|website=www.15min.lt|accessdate=14 June 2014}}</ref>
=== Documentary films ===
* 1994 – ''Wounds of Karabakh'' ([[Tsvetana Paskaleva]])<ref>{{cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/37424933 |title=Wounds of Karabakh |publisher=Vimeo.com |date=2012 |accessdate=2015-03-25}}</ref> * 2011 – ''Refugee: a long journey of Anar Yusubov'' (dir. Cem Oguz) * 2012 – ''Infinite Corridor / Sonu olmayan dəhliz'' (dir. Richardas Lopaitis)
=== Fictional films === * 1993 – [[The Squall (1993 film)|The Squall]] (dir. [[Jeyhun Mirzayev]]) * 1993 – ''Haray'' (dir. Oruj Gurbanov) * 2012 – [[Xoca]] (dir. Vahid Mustafayev) * 2012 – [[Dolu (film)|Dolu]] (dir. Elkhan Jafarov)
== Music == A list of musical works dedicated to the Khojaly Massacre and related events:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Composition ! Artist ! Notes |- |1993 |[[Always (Aziza Mustafa Zadeh album)|Crying Earth]] |[[Aziza Mustafa Zadeh]] |From the album ''[[Always (Aziza Mustafa Zadeh album)|Always]]'' |- | 1993 | ''Ya Karabağ, Ya Ölüm'' | [[Arif Şirin|Ozan Arif]] | |- | 1995 | ''Salam, Dar Ağacı'' | [[Shamistan Alizamanli]] | |- | 1996 | ''Ya Qarabağ, Ya Ölüm'' | [[Dayirman]] | from the album ''[[Qurd (album)|Qurd]]''<ref>{{cite web|last=Blair|first=Betty|title=Dayirman - For a New Rap Music Generation|url=http://www.azer.com/aiweb/categories/magazine/91_folder/91_articles/91_dayirman.html|work=Azer.com|publisher=[[Azerbaijan International]]|accessdate=31 May 2013}}</ref> |- | 2010 | ''Justice for Khojaly'' | [[Dayirman]] featuring [[Toni Blackman]] | |- | 2012 | ''The Khojaly Requiem '' | [[:ru:Чайковский, Александр Владимирович|Alexander Tchaikovsky]] | a symphony<ref>[http://news.day.az/culture/347493.html Alexander Tchaikovsky: 'By writing the Khojaly Requiem, I wanted to show support for those who survived the war']. ''Day.az''. 3 August 2012.</ref> |- | 2012 | ''Galin Donek Eve'' | Mina Sovetski | Soundtrack from [[Xoca]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Vishnevsky |first1=Felix |title=Azərbaycanlı qalmaqallı müğənni səhnəyə qayıdır |url=http://gun.az/showbiz/94086 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140824015239/http://gun.az/showbiz/94086 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 August 2014 |website=gun.az |accessdate=24 August 2014 |language=Azerbaijani }}</ref> |- | 2013 | ''Khojaly 613'' | Pierre Thilloy | a symphony<ref>{{cite web|title=World première of Khojaly 613 by Pierre Thilloy moves a Parisian audience|url=http://en.apa.az/news_world_premi__re_of_khojaly_613_by_pierre__188377.html|work=En.apa.az|accessdate=28 February 2013}}</ref> |}
== Sports == On 11 May 2014, [[Arda Turan]], of [[Athletico Madrid]], was announced as a [[goodwill ambassador]] for Khojaly Massacre.<ref>{{cite web|title=Arda Turan 'Hocalı' mesajı yayınladı |url=http://www.zaman.com.tr/spor_arda-turan-hocali-mesaji-yayinladi_2202180.html |work=www.zaman.com.tr |accessdate=11 May 2014 |language=Turkish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140512214749/http://www.zaman.com.tr/spor_arda-turan-hocali-mesaji-yayinladi_2202180.html |archivedate=12 May 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Meaningful Message from Arda Turan|url=http://van.habermonitor.com/en/haber/detay/meaningful-message-from-arda-turan/301386/|work=van.habermonitor.com|accessdate=11 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|script-title=ru:АРДА Туран: В финале Лиги чемпионов не мог найти себе места, вот и поменял костюм на "спортивку"|url=http://www.azerisport.com/football/20140529110645865.html|work=www.azerisport.com|accessdate=29 May 2014|language=Russian}}</ref> Turan's ambassador activities are aimed to raise awareness about this issue and promoting world peace.<ref>{{cite web|title=Atletico Madrid FC to commemorate Khojaly victims |url=http://www.azertag.gov.az/en/node/1195864 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140511105447/http://www.azertag.gov.az/en/node/1195864 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=11 May 2014 |work=www.azertag.gov.a |accessdate=11 May 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Arda Hocalı kurbanlarını unutmadı|url=http://www.aljazeera.com.tr/haber/arda-hocali-kurbanlarini-unutmadi|work=www.aljazeera.com.tr|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]|accessdate=11 May 2014}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Khojaly Massacre]] *[[Black January]] *[[March Days]]
